The politics of greed were introduced with Mrs Thatcher but hardly rejected by Tony Blair who still courted the rich & lived life centre stage. As a country we have encouraged self-centred behaviour and rewarded hard profit with extra tax dodges and elevated 'celebrity' lifestyles. We have forgotten that all lives are important and that the wealthy largely succeed because of the contribution of the working class.  There absolutely should be reward for leadership and the risks taken by entrepreneurs but not at the expense of compassion. We have sold off our housing and our essential assets to overseas organisations without thought of where the money came from or what impact it was having on our society.  The wealth gap is so huge now that most people have no chance of progressing.  Theresa May is very much a product of this history and her lack of compassion a clarion blast for why things must change.
A brilliant summing up of where the country is now!!!

Thank you Jenny, that is what I mean.  Am not advocating that everyone should get equal shares but it should be more equal than it currently is or society cannot operate in a  hopeful, motivated fashion, which is how the economy improves for all. Also, Tracey, it very much depends where you live regarding successful business. If your area is economically successful with more job opportunities and decent wages, I think that informs your view in an unconsciously unbalanced way. Unless you live somewhere where it's really hard to get work, even with excellent qualifications, then it's hard to appreciate.  Only then do you suddenly gain a whole new understanding on how easy it is to hit a downward spiral.  It seems to me that we continue to shoehorn more and more jobs into already crowded areas, creating population pressures with all their associated complications of doctors, dentists, school places, traffic issues and pollution. If jobs were spread out more evenly around the country there would be better conditions for all. Incidentally, in answer to your question, working class to me is pretty much all of us that work for someone else! Middle class is almost a thing of the past since we all got squashed!

Political point scoring? Equally as guilty? Are you being serious? 

2013 - Boris Johnson overrules the ruling body of the London Fire Brigade and uses legal action to inflict £29m in cuts. Closing 10 fire stations, cutting firefighters by 552, losing 14 fire engines and cutting minimum staffing levels from 5 to 4. By the time he steps down as Mayor of London he inflicts a further £100m in cuts to £130m total and the loss of 700 firefighters. Fire prevention measures carried out by the service drop by over 25%.

2013 - All Party Parliamentary Group on Fire Safety and Rescue produces a report strongly recommending installation of fire suppression systems and sprinklers in 4000 tower blocks throughout Britain. The Grenfell residents action group publishes a report warning that their landlord is putting their safety at risk by restricting the access ways to their car park. They are ignored by their landlord.

2013 - 2016 Conservative housing ministers sit on All Party report without action, promising they are "looking at it", including housing minister Gavin Barwell.

2016 - Conservatives vote against a Labour motion to make sure all landlords and housing associations ensure residences are fit for human occupation, including provisions for fire safety. The motion is denied by 312 votes to 219. 72 of the MP's voting against are landlords. The Grenfell residents action group publish a report warning people will die in a fire before the landlord takes notice of their poor fire safety provisions. They are ignored by their landlord.

2017 - Ex housing minister Gavin Barwell becomes Prime Minister Theresa May's chief of staff. He never actions the All Party Parliamentary report recommendations.

Theresa May and no other living politician of any political shade can take the blame for the Grenfell fire disaster. It has been an accident waiting to happen, after decades of failed housing policy and faulty shuttered-concrete building techniques dating back half a century. Ronan Point – under a Labour government – proved that the prefabricated high-rise architecture of the post-war era was a death-trap in the making. Both Labour and the Tories of the 1960s and 1970s oversaw such sprawling projects. Now, the blackened hulk of Grenfell, under a 21st-century Tory government, underlines the past folly of creating and patching up bunkers in the sky without adequate respect for fire safety. These hideous towers are inhuman, unsafe and most should have been torn down, not covered in flammable composite cladding. The exact cause, route of spread and final toll of this inferno have yet to be found.  One thing is certain: no one party or politician can wholly be blamed nor cover themselves in glory on UK housing policy since the 1960s.  State planning and local authority ownership, and privatised, devolved management – both failed the residents of Grenfell Tower.

What people in distress need is someone to listen.  To have someone say to them " I know best what you need, let me get on with it" is  infuriating and disempowering. It just continues the problem that their attempts to raise concerns fell on deaf ears in the past.       She needed to do both.

But they didn't understand! It is an incredibly complex field. There were lots of people listening and the emergency services were also people in distress but knowing what needs to be done.
For example, one reason the fire spread so fast was because it was a warm night. Most flats had windows open so as the fire reached the cladding it was sucked into the rooms by the chimney effect which would then set fire to curtains, furniture etc. If it had been midwinter the fire would have been slower. 
The people didn't talk to her when she came, they shouted and heckled, as she knew they would. But she had already set in motion the essential things to manage the situation.

Of course they didn't understand, and of course it's complex. And of course there were plenty of people listening, but those listening did not have the clout to take decisions forward.  
It is vital that the people who will take the decisions are seen to listen to the people affected. There is nothing in the world so belittling as to take it for granted that what you see as the right course of action on behalf of others is actually the right thing as they perceive it, and that they will appreciate you for it.    Those in power owe it absolutely to those affected to ask how they are, and be seen to include their input in the decisions taken.   
This is the whole problem at the root of the whole sorry situation. No-one listened to the residents, and they were told "we know best and we are already doing the best we can for you".  
No wonder they feel it is at last time that the Prime Minister listened.
She needed to grant them the respect of going to hear them, and to give them that safety valve for their anger.
She did, on day two having dealt with the urgent stuff on day one.
